resources.string: PassGo is a graphical password scheme derived from the \"Go Game\", an accent Chinese game, and that is where the name comes from.
3D PassGo extends PassGo to a 3D space: a user draws dots and/or lines on a 3D grid. The 3D grid can be optionally rotated and zoomed in or out to further improve the security.

In PassGo, the security can be fine-tuned by adjusting the grid size which is available from 1x1x1 to 19x19x19. In addition, PassGo allows multiple strokes, namely you can draw multiple dots and lines. The larger the grid size is and the larger the stroke number is, the more secure your passwrod will be. Such, a user can choose a password at any desired security level with appropriate usability.
How do I enter a PassGo?
In PassGo, a user clicks or draws through the intersections of a grid, as a way to input a password.
How do I draw a dot?
To draw a dot, touch an intersection on the grid and then lift your finger.
How do I draw a line?
To draw a line, touch multiple intersections continuously and then lift your finger.
How do I rotate the grid?
Touch the screen just around(not too far) or inside the grid without touching any intersections, and then keep moving on the screen, the grid will rotate.
How do I zoom in or out the grid?
Place two fingers on the grid and then adjust the distance between the two fingers, the grid will zoom in or out.
How do I move the grid?
Do I have to draw PassGo in exactly the same way as how I set up?

Yes. PassGo requires to be drawn in EXACTLY the same way as how it was set up. For example, if you click the an intersection twice when you set up PassGo, then you must click the same intersection twice when you login, even though you only see one dot on the grid (the other dot is overlapped in this case).
PassGo do not match, try again
Your PassGo will be saved as
PassGo has not been set up yet!
PINs do not match, try again
